docs.lead_paragraph: The computer printout that Pat and Ben Christen picked up along with their son's medicine included a string of warnings: Dry mouth. Constipation. Blurred vision. Drowsiness. Dizziness. These were just a few of the side effects of the drug imipramine, which a psychiatrist had prescribed for the Christens' 7-year-old son, Cory, who suffered from attention deficit disorder. Cory had been taking the drug for several months when his second-grade teacher noticed that his hands were trembling. His parents checked the warning sheet for guidance, but ''there was nothing in it,'' Mrs. Christen said. Soon after, while he was leaning over a school water fountain to take a sip on the way to gym class, Cory collapsed and died. ''His heart just gave out,'' his mother said.

headline.main: Faulty Warning Labels Add to Risk in Prescription Drugs

docs.abstract: Growing concern about deaths and injuries from prescription drugs spurs Food and Drug Administration to implement rule allowing it to require drug makers to publish 'med guides,' Government-approved patient brochures, for riskiest prescription drugs; was blocked by Congress in earlier effort to require guides for all prescription drugs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The computer printout that Pat and Ben Christen picked up along with their son's medicine included a string of warnings: Dry mouth. Constipation. Blurred vision. Drowsiness. Dizziness. These were just a few of the side effects of the drug imipramine,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Helen McLaughlin was 73 years old when, relatives say, a mix-up in prescription drugs took her life. In death, she became a statistic that is causing increasing anxiety among health care experts and Federal regulators: the tens of thousands of Americans who are killed each year not by illness, but by medication intended to treat it. In March 1997, Mrs. McLaughlin, a widow who lived with her two daughters in Elizabeth, N.J., walked into the pharmacy department of her local Shop-Rite supermarket to fill a prescription for chlorpromazine, an antipsychotic medication. She walked out, according to her son Charles and a lawyer, Michael S. Smith, who is suing Shop-Rite on behalf of her family, with a drug that has a nearly identical name, chlorpropamide, which is used by diabetics to lower their blood sugar.

headline.main: The Boom in Medications Brings Rise in Fatal Risks

docs.abstract: First of two articles, Death by Prescription, notes that increasing number of Americans are killed each year not by illness, but by medication intended to treat it; discusses case of Helen McLaughlin, 73-year-old woman from Elizabeth, NJ, who relatives say died because of mix-up in prescription medication she was taking; says increase in medications and in number of prescriptions has created growing risk that patients will be killed or injured by reactions or mistakes; says doctors are struggling to keep up with warnings and pharmacists are often overburdened; graph; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Helen McLaughlin was 73 years old when, relatives say, a mix-up in prescription drugs took her life. In death, she became a statistic that is causing increasing anxiety among health care experts and Federal regulators: the tens of thousands of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Until recently, very few people lived to be more than 100. But with the number of centenarians rocketing upward, statisticians and scientists have begun studying them -- and challenging some of the conventional wisdom about the very old. These are not necessarily people at the end of the line, deteriorating into extreme age. Rather, many show patterns of health that are as surprising as they are mysterious. For example, the rate at which people die rises steadily from middle age up through the 80's. But then, death rates decline. After age 110, the death rate drops back to that for people in their 80's.

headline.main: Life at Age 100 Is Surprisingly Healthy

docs.abstract: Statisticians and scientists are increasingly studying centenarians, with their numbers steadily rising; many of such older people shows patterns of health that are as surprising as they are mysterious; for example, rate at which people die rises steadily from middle age up through the 80's; but then, death rates decline; after age 110, death rate drops back to that for people in their 80's; photo shows six generations of one family, ranging from Sara Knauss, 118, to her great-great-great-grandson Bradley Patton, 3 (M)
